üß†This is a fantastic game, a mercenary squad simulator set in an alternate Middle Ages world. It offers everything from managing the camp to combat based on turn-taking. The storyline doesn't matter or, rather, it is a minor issue - the game is subdivided into regions/locations, and each has its main quest. If not, the focus is gameplay - travel, collect resources (there's crafting), improve your squad overall skills (there's a progression bar for the entire squad), and individual fighters (there are seven classes, each with three subclasses), and complete quests (generated in the tavern and as part of the location's main quest chain).
The game is so worth the money and can actually give a delightful experience.

It looks that Wartales took a lot from Battle Brothers and Northgard as far as the management side is concerned. However, the question remains; if you're going to take the mechanics, why not take all the successful ones? In this sense, Wartales is a paradox to me. I enjoy the game, but it is missing a heap of features that are both obvious and not obvious.

Wartales has only five quest types generated which are to defeat an enemy team or buy here and sell there. The rest of the one-time tasks are also two: kill the boss of the location, clear the camp, and find the local crypt. That's all, in fact, there was a lot of them in Battle Brothers if you remember. Besides those, there were also hunting and tracking, escorting of caravans, delivery, artifact searches, and crises. Wartales is missing all of these.

Wartales has equipped the players with seven different character classes in total. The weapon types assigned to the classes are very specific: the axes, the maces, the swords, the spears, the daggers, the bows, and the brass knuckles. The three subclasses for each type of weapon are not very thrilling - each one has only two skills, which together form build variety. The rest of the subclass is identical. Do you still recall the number of skills that were available in Battle Brothers? You can say that Wartales does not even offer one-third of that variety.

To begin with, I considered the game's fight to be a combination of the ones in Heroes of Might and Magic, Banner Saga, and yes, it is similar in concept and totally similar in many ways. There are still some small differences, like half-steps, but in the end, not much has changed. Is this a disadvantage? I doubt it, because the developers have already made various battle types - battles in the dark tombs where you still have to find the enemy; a battle with a nightmare, where the enemies are causing fear effect on characters;
an arena - three 4x4 battles with conditions and a boss fight at the end;
capturing bandit/robber camps - where you first weaken the garrison by finding individual groups of bandits/robbers scurrying around.
The combat is usually quite pleasant and stimulating; it is always a good time to engage in combat. The only thing is, however, that preparation for battle is a bit tiresome. In Banner Saga, for instance, you can see on icons which characters are taking part in the battle, and the arena is not as large and spacious as in this game, but you get used to it very fast.

The maps are quite dynamic and interactive since there are various items distributed on the maps that can be used - healing with herbs, throwing the abandoned hatchet lying nearby at the enemy. A few maps have the end-of-turn mechanics that deal area-of-effect damage, for instance, a cave collapse or lightning, and also have areas that block players, like fog that conceals only the enemies (not the players. In the fog, the enemies can see your soldiers perfectly well) and mud that slows down (thankfully, it works for both enemies and players). Everything seems to be alright, but there is a very urgent need for a height and cover mechanics. The whole map is flat in Wartales. The game doesn't let characters go up or get down anyplace or hide anywhere. Basically, there is no place to go up and nothing to get down the line.

For me the squad tactics are a very irritating part of the game. Firstly, let me explain how almost every battle goes (with rare exceptions): at the beginning of the battle the enemies are distributed all over the map. And there are also spawn points where your fighters can be positioned. And these spawn points are the main issue. It seems that prior to the battle, some unseen force has taken all your fighters, along with all the enemy fighters, and done the following: squeezed them in its hand, shaken them up thoroughly and then just thrown them on the map. What is the mercenaries' formation? What strategy? It doesn't matter here. All the fighters will be dispersed across the map in pairs, threes, or fives. Totally random. It is nearly impossible to gather your whole squad at the beginning of the battle and come up with some sort of formation. What you can only hope for is that the spawn points of your squad are not too far apart so you can place all your characters in one area of the map at least. It is quite ironic that the game has squad upgrades which allow you to create these spots closer to each other at the beginning of the battle.
That is my personal opinion and the instances I hold on to.

‚úÖThe Good.
- Open world with exploration
- Professions add depth
- Co-op/party play support
- Emergent stories and your own mercenary tale

‚ùåThe Bad.
- Battles can become long and tedious
- NPCs feel lifeless
- Limited character customization depth
- Interface is not always intuitive

üßæConclusion.
The game is amazing. Lively visuals, impressive opponents, glorious party management, and mainly the camp. An attractive vast map and stealthily grinding resources through simple games. It is all captivating to discover, and also very enjoyable to do. 
There is plenty of content and the game remains fascinating. For a long time I have been looking for a game that lets you play with your own music in the background (so far I have not found anything similar except for Civilization V). Definitely, it is a must-have.

üí¨In my two-decade long gaming profession, I may have encountered nothing better than Wartales the best turn-based tactical strategy game with RPG elements. This is a very strong statement and I will try to give reasons for it.

üéÆThe developers, Shiro Studio, who are behind the game Wartales, have managed to make a very genius, varied and large-scale fight system. At first, it is quite similar to the Expeditions series from Logic Artists but during the course of the game, it becomes evident that Shiro has really gone deeper and farther in terms of combat.

Wartales is a title where more than 50+ warriors can be battling in the same period on the warfront, with a large number of classes and kinds of unit already being available to take charge. The playing experience is marked by incessant development of squads and by a slow change of tactics and strategy during confrontations. Indeed, this is an uncommon turn-based game where wining the battle depends upon both tactical and strategic reasoning, and in one fight, the gamer may be directing at once two or three different tactical units, each having its own set of combat goals and manner of fighting.

Wartales delivers an amazing world of combat and has also an equally advanced system of crafting, thus the player can completely immerse himself in the surrounding world where 90% of the inventory items can and should be crafted which means bringing up a camp, learning different crafts, and finding out and using more and more features.

As a squad develops, it becomes possible to create something akin to a PMC with a network of bases and logistics across all game regions through a trading post system. This system is not yet fully developed; in particular, there is no regular passive income, but even the existing updates significantly enhance the gameplay.

Wartales is remarkable for its genuinely vast open world that is intricately mixed with several interesting stories through which the player slowly unveils the history. It is true that the developers did a few wrong things with the individual region scenarios, such as some NPCs not changing their behavior after the completion, which lessens the feeling of influence. On the other hand, completing the region scenarios and unveiling their connections offer more than the typical storyline found in other similar games.

Freedom of squad development is the last thing that Wartales gives to you. You can go beyond just being a mercenary and manage a trading company, set up an organized crime group, or even put together an archaeological expedition, and then you can either put all your money into this area or spread your investments among many areas at once. The Arena has exciting gladiator battles, and you can also enjoy fun turn-based rugby games, and with the "Pirates of Balerion" DLC, you can not only build a ship but also start conquering the archipelago that is infested with pirates. This DLC is like a separate game already, equipped with a whole series of new, interesting mechanics to engage with.

üëçPositive.
+ Deep tactical combat.
+ Strong party management.
+ Good replayability.
+ Immersive medieval world.

üëéNegative.
- Gameplay loop can drag.
- Thin overarching narrative.
- Grindy progression.
- Stutters especially with large parties or late game.

üßæSummary.
To sum up, Wartales has been, in my opinion, the best turn-based tactical strategy game with RPG features that I have ever experienced. If titles like Disciples, Darkest Dungeon, Expeditions, Banner Saga, and the like are your thing, then this game is a smart pick that will provide you with endless fun for hours on end.

Holy crap this game is sick.
It flew completely under my radar and I haven't seen any hype around it online, got recommended to me by my steam recommendations.

The amount of customization is insane.

Then you get hit with random passive unlocks based on dynamic use of particular equipment (Using shields may unlock a passive for your character to make shields more effective) or even esoteric things like NPC interactions or combat interactions (Getting scared by a ghost could make a character have an event where they become less fearful, getting poisoned enough times makes them resilient, etc.)

Then you get into the dynamic crafting systems and equipment productions.
Then the game hits you with the camp upgrade mechanic and you go from a squad of homeless peasants to a full blown miniature army with a mobile town around you.
Then you get hit with the layers of permanent weapon and armor upgrades.
Then just when you thought the game was running out of customization, you find out each starting choice has different repeatable objectives that unlock permanent upgrades in another tree.

The longer I play, the more the onion peels back to reveal deeper and deeper complexity and each time it makes me more excited for a replay.
I think the standard gameplay loop will be fairly consistent and probably get stale after a while, but the amount of variance and the multiple levels of horizontal and vertical progression will keep it fresh for a very long time.
I can definitely see myself digging into a very long campaign and then starting over and trying things a completely different way.

In Wartales, you assemble and manage a band of medieval mercenaries, fighting battles and cooking meals. Units have different classes, which can be developed into specialized builds. All this happens in a large open 2D map, with some light story/RPG elements mixed in (a "tactical RPG").

The combat system is turn-based, with each side taking turns with individual units.  If the enemy has equal numbers, you will move one unit, then they will move one unit, and so on.  You can freely choose which unit to move, but that unit must take all of its actions for that turn.  The order in which the computer moves its units is fixed, so you can target the one that is going to move next.

Each unit has active and passive abilities.  The active abilities require spending "valor points", which are in a pool shared by your entire team.  Certain actions, such as striking multiple units with a single attack, will earn a valor point.  Valor point management is a key factor in both your tactics and the way you build units.

Feeding and paying your troops is also important.  There are camp upgrades that make these easier.  You can learn a variety of recipes, which require different ingredients that can be purchased or scavenged.  Some recipes can be combined into "feasts", which provide more nutrition per ingredient and also give bonuses to the entire warband.

You can craft armor, weapons, and gear.  One significant annoyance is that some of the gathering and crafting actions require playing a real-time mini-game, usually based on clicking at just the right time. Some of these can be ignored, e.g. you can do without fish or superior gear, but sometimes skills like mining and woodcutting are used to clear debris.  While most of these are pretty easy (crafting at the forge seems a bit finicky), the game would be better off without them.  There are also some non-real-time puzzles, e.g. a sliding tile game in Ancient Tombs and a Mastermind game when deciphering artifacts, that are pretty simple.

The game lets you adjust the difficulty for combat and troop management independently, so you can configure it to your liking.

The game was generally stable, with no crashes, but sometimes it freezes up for 10-15 seconds while launching for no apparent reason.  If you get a black screen, don't let Windows kill it right away.

At a high level, its similar to Battle Brothers, but it plays very differently.  Notably, BB required you to adjust your tactics significantly based on the nature of the enemy.  With the exception of rat nest clearing and the odd "boss" fight, combat in Wartales has more of a rinse-and-repeat feel.  This is why I'm stopping about halfway through the campaign.  With 40+ hours spent, I definitely got my money's worth, but I just don't feel the need to finish.

[h3] TLDR: [/h3] Tried during Free Play Weekend. Lots of fun and potential, but buggy and feels incomplete. I do not recommend at full price.

[h1] The Pros [+] [/h1]
[list]
    [*] Aesthetically and mechanically, the world is rough, hostile, and basic, as it should be for a band of fictional Medieval Mercenaries. No "magicking" your way out of even the basic things.

    [*] The Profession minigames are well conceptualized, not too difficult and gratifying to perfect.

    [*] The Combat system is well designed. Tactics, strategy, and logistics all play an important role, and the Valour point system does not let you monotonously cheese your way through things. 

    [*] Character progression, interpersonal relationships between mercenaries, and the overall development of your warband are all well conceptualized. Every new gain is felt, as is every loss. I cursed up a storm when my blacksmith was lost clearing out a nest of Plague rats.
[/list]

[h1] The Cons [-] [/h1]
[list]
    [*] Bugs - Frequent animation freezes can be a real nuisance, especially when you are trying to get the timing on Profession QTE's just right. Also, after a certain point, black screens become more and more frequent, forcing me to restart the game, sometimes a full reboot.

    [*] The crime and theft system is on the wrong side of egregious. When you steal, it is always detected. Chances at stealth simply do not exist. Worst of all are the Guard patrols, which are too many and ridiculously committed to running you down, even at the lower Wanted levels. This is supposed to be a Medieval setting, not Cyberpunk.

    [*] Story Elements - Secondary, at best. Questlines and unique traits that are supposed to be present with unique recruits are absent due to either bugs or incomplete design. Damned disappointing.
[/list]

[h3] Conclusion: [/h3] Get on sale. Standard price is too much, especially with all the expensive DLC.

Pretty interesting to start with, gets old pretty fast as you find out how shallow most of its systems are.

Core gameplay loop consists of taking on contracts at the tavern, *slowly* wandering about the map, fulfilling contracts (usually combat encounters) and doing side-quests with very limited choices, then returning to town to collect on completed contracts. The rest is mostly just managing supplies by cooking stuff with purchased salt supply, and equipping the party who has very inflexible mastery over only their initial weapon type. The town's blacksmith doesn't sell any equipment at all and you mostly have to smith stuff yourself with the variety of resources you collect around the map. 

Turn-based combat is manageable when you have a small band of troops, gets increasingly tedious as it gets larger and battles become a slogfest. Combat UI isn't great either, could've highlighted allied and enemy troops with different colors, as every human unit looks similar; move distance for both enemies and allies could've been shown by default by simply hovering or selecting them, instead of being a two step process of having to select units and hover over the move command for every unit.

Combat skill-tree is a bit questionable in design, I'm wondering why I shouldn't just fill the party with berserkers whose combat efficiency far surpasses most other unit classes. It's also annoying that many classes can't be equipped with any (light, medium, heavy)armor until lvl 3, which takes quite a few combat encounters to grind out.

Non-combat profession system is kinda interesting, but apparently there's an epidemic of short term memory loss in the middle ages where all experience is lost if you switch from one profession to another, even if they share the same mini-game like woodcutting and mining.  Personally I don't mind the mini-games that come with most of them, except fishing, which is poorly explained.

Roleplaying is pretty limited. In the first area you can make morally-grey binary choices to side with either the villagers of the county or desperate neighboring refugees. As far as your party member goes, all of your troops are pretty interchangeable; once in a while while camping, there might be randomized events with minor choices. 

The game is also rather buggy and crashed several times.

4/5 of the way through the main game, I hit the level limit... I mean come on, including all the DLCs, there's tons of content to explore and no more progress to be made with my troop.
- Despite the limited fast-travel system, you will spend A LOT of time walking VERY SLOWLY between locations scattered across a continent, with ways constantly blocked by (in)conveniently placed rivers and mountains. That funnelling of your exploration I could understand if this were a linear plot, but it's not, it's open world. There are horses aplenty in the world, but can you ride them? No. Can you buy a wagon like all the merchants have? No.
- You can run, but only for a very short time before your stamina is exhausted. Does dropping into a tracker camp, or stopping to chat and trade with a merchant restore you stamina? No, oh but walking (slowly) does...
- Many resources are in short supply. Wood is one of them, despite you being constantly surrounded by forests and (in my case) having a master woodcutter along. You can pick it up off the ground, buy it occasionally or chop it at specially sanctioned wood-chopping stations where a certain amount of wood may be chopped within a fixed time period.
- Speaking of chopping wood - the mini games, Oh my God! They were an attractive and really fun part of the game when I first started, but they wear thin, VERY quickly. Picking locks, mining, forging, fishing etc all become tedious in the extreme.
- Animals are, by and large not very useful. You can encounter and recruit half a dozen different species. Horses are useful for carrying stuff and in the early game, bears make good tanks. After that, I got rid of all my non-horse animals. Trying to keep them alive on the battlefield was just a massive hassle.
- Battles are slow. Even with the animations turned up to maximum speed, they are slow. Some animations don't make sense, and you always have to wait for them to finish. Defeated enemies leaving arenas, for example. Or lightning strikes - these take place one at a time and consist of two animations, one small explosion followed by the actual bolt. These sound like minor things, but they add up and end up becoming annoying. Later in the game when there can be 40+ combatants, battles can become a bit of a chore. Why won't those 30 under-levelled and massively out-matched wolves run away until you have slaughtered 26 of them? Who knows. Why did they attack in the first place?
-Speaking of which, you have complete freedom to move your mercs to any of the available starting points in each battle, but no control at all over where they initially spawn. This means you will have to reposition most of your mercs in EVERY SINGLE battle. Why the game chooses to hide your tanks at the back or make the front like knife-wielders and archers, with alarming regularity, I have no idea.
- I hate the escape battles in cursed villages with a passion - so incredibly tedious, slow-paced and poorly designed.
- Cooking is tedious (and you'll need to do a lot of it to maximise your food usage). There's not one window where everything happens. Each recipe cooked is a series of pop-ups and confirmation clicks, with a drop back to the camp screen to show your cook 'receiving' the cooked items. It would be a lot easier if you could cook more than one thing at a time, but you can't.
- Loot, like in so many games, is by and large useless and just stuff to sell. You'll be waiting for high-level forged items and legendary items (plus the money to upgrade them).
- There are some natural resources lying around that you can't seem to reach - usually iron ore in the sides of hills, where you can't seem to get your characters close enough to pick it up - better pathfinding would help - see below.
- When you are buying things, you can't scroll your inventory. Nor can you see how many of anything you already have, so you have to either just buy everything you think you need, or keep dropping out of the trade screen to check.
- The tavern DLC is fun for a couple of hours, then just becomes a pointless background detail where you are constantly plagued by the same old requests over again. +10 Influence - oh, yay! I already have 8000... the tavern has a different currency for some inexplicable reason, which you can withdraw in very limited quantities. It's handy, but doesn't ultimately have much game impact. My tavern currently has around 40,000 currency and there's literally nothing to do with it.
- The Feif DLC is very similar (and also has yet another currency). Once you've completed your feif after a few hours, it becomes background fodder. You can't withdraw the currency. It has almost no impact on the main game. There's no point in sending any mercs you garrison there on missions because there's nothing to do with the proceeds. Bad relations with other countries have absolutely no effect on you. It all feels a bit pointless.
- All the DLC are quite expensive for what they are, and they don't seem to add much to the game. Each seems like a good idea poorly and minimally executed.
- The pathfinding is really bad - inexcusable in this day and age. Getting across bridges and round small, sometimes barely visible lumps in the ground, becomes very tiresome. What tends to happen is they walk until they hit some sort of (usually visible, but not always) obstacle then just stop. The number of times I've had to click on resources, merchant groups or pitons multiple times to interact with them is annoying. Having to click 3 or 4 times on a piton whilst running from the guard because your guys just dumbly stand next to it is rather frustrating.
- Being a bad guys is tough. The game implies it's a perfectly valid option, but the rewards are few and constantly dodging the guards who are, until later in the game, always more powerful than you, is just not worth it. You can't befriend bandits or anything like that - again, it feels a bit pointless. Robbing the odd merchant of a bit of cheese to reduce your food bill is about all it's worth bothering with.
- And finally, there is the story & tutorials. Oh. My. God. Tiltren, the usual starting province is well written and provides a decent grounding in the basics. After that, good luck! You will inevitably spend a small age walking backwards and forward (and eventually Googling) trying to work out what the hell you have to do next or how certain mechanics work or where you find a resource you apparently suddenly need. The solve the murder quest was particularly irritating.
